text: Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that -

text: Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them? Doctor: No. You should not. You’re done. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping.

text: Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Everybody. Family Member: Not me, but yeah, them. Doctor: Right. Everybody that, so, you have one, it’s, it’s a mutation in the gene. You have two copies of the gene. It’s, you know, so there’s a one and four chance you could pass it on because two copies come from your, their mother, and so, the mother contributes one, you contribute one. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: There’s a fifty/fifty chance, you could contribute a good one or bad one, so they -- you know – does that make sense? Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
